title: Design a heater for indoor swimming pool

(10 points, suggested time 20 minutes) A group of students is asked to design a heater for an indoor swimming pool using an electrically insulated current-carrying wire. The energy from the wire heats the water. The heater should deliver <math alttext="10 kilowatts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>10 kW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of power to the water in the pool. (a) The students use wire that has a cross-sectional area of <math alttext="1.3 times 10 to the negative 5 power, meters squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and a resistivity of <math alttext="3.0 times 10 to the negative 6 power, ohm meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. They have access to a <math alttext="240 volt" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>240 V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> power supply. Calculate the length of the wire needed to construct the heater.

(b) The wire is completely submerged in the water, and the heater is turned on. After a while, both the water and the air above it are noticeably warmer. i. Identify and describe both the primary process that transfers energy through the wire’s electrical insulation and the primary process that transfers energy through the water. ii. The door to the pool area is open, and the air outside is colder than the air in the pool area. The heater must remain on to maintain a constant water temperature that is greater than the air temperature in the pool area. Explain how the first and second laws of thermodynamics can be applied to show that this must occur.

The door to the pool area is then closed so that energy transfer and air transfer into and out of the area are negligible. After some time the air in the pool area becomes warmer. (c) On the graph below, sketch the thermodynamic process that the air in the pool area undergoes as it becomes warmer. Compare the amount <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of energy transferred to the air by heating to the change <math alttext="delta U" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the air’s internal energy.

(d) When the temperature of the room is <math alttext="276 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>276 K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the air pressure is <math alttext="1.0 times 10 to the fifth power, pascals" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Pa</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the force exerted by the air in the room on a door that measures <math alttext="2.0 meters" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>2.0 m</mtext></mrow></math> by <math alttext="0.90 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.90 m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when the temperature of the room is <math alttext="310 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>310 K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
